node.title: Melbourne protests spark safety fears among politicians as PM criticises violent scenes
node.alt: Prime Minister Scott Morrison speaks to media, November 2021.
node.description: The Prime Minister says he understands the frustration caused by COVID-19 restrictions, but it is no excuse for the threats and intimidation seen at protests in Melbourne on the weekend.
node.content:
["Prime Minister Scott Morrison says he understands the frustration that drove violent protests in Melbourne on the weekend, and has\u00a0called on governments to take a step back from interfering in people's personal lives.", "Protesters against a pandemic management bill in Victoria were seen marching through Melbourne carrying nooses and a gallows,\u00a0and chanting threats to kill state Premier Daniel Andrews.", "Mr Morrison said people were rightly frustrated by the pandemic, but it was no excuse for violent behaviour.", "\"Those threats and intimidation have\u00a0no place in Australia,\" Mr Morrison said.", "\"We're a civil peaceful society. [When]\u00a0we have disagreements, we don't handle them with violence \u2026 there can be no tolerance for that.\"", "", "
Protesters opposing a Victorian pandemic bill were seen calling\u00a0for violence against politicians in a demonstration on the weekend.(AAP: Joel Carrett)
", "But Mr Morrison said the frustration was driven by governments \"telling Australians what to do\" throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, and it was time for strict public health measures to be rolled back.", "\"It's time for governments to step back and for Australians to take their lives back,\" he said.", "
Federal politicians fear for safety\u00a0following protests
", "Several federal politicians have raised serious concerns for their safety following the weekend's protests.", "Victorian Police have confirmed they are investigating threats made against state politicians during protests against the state government's pandemic laws.", "Independent senator Jacqui Lambie said it was a frightening sight.", "\"If you want to go out there and protest, be my guest. You've got your freedoms to do that, we're all Australian,\" Senator Lambie said.", "\"But this is going way overboard. This is absolutely frightening, to be honest with you.\"", "Federal Labor MP Tanya Plibersek said far-right ideology was\u00a0evidently on the rise across the country.", "\"Of course people have the right to express an opinion \u2026\u00a0that should never come with threats to the health or safety of other Australians,\" Ms Plibersek said.", "Fear for the safety of elected leaders has been heightened since British Conservative MP Sir David Amess was stabbed to death during a constituent meeting last month.", "Following that incident, several politicians in Australia raised concerns for their safety.", "The government is consulting with the Australian Federal Police commissioner on whether security measures to protect politicians need to be changed.", "", "
WA's COVID-19 reopening roadmap
"]
